title: 108_s348
content: The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" establishes a deduction for higher education expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The deduction amount is subject to limitations based on applicable dollar limits for each taxable year. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" sets deduction limits for higher education expenses based on taxable years: $8,000 for 2003 and $12,000 for 2004 onwards. The deduction amount is reduced based on modified adjusted gross income. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" sets deduction limits for higher education expenses based on taxable years. The deduction amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, which is calculated without considering specific sections and after applying certain provisions. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" sets deduction limits for higher education expenses based on taxable years. Adjusted gross income for deduction purposes excludes specific sections. Dollar amounts for inflation adjustments increase annually based on cost-of-living adjustments. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" adjusts deduction limits for higher education expenses based on taxable years. Adjusted gross income excludes specific sections for deduction purposes. Dollar amounts are annually adjusted for inflation based on cost-of-living adjustments. Section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include qualified tuition and related expenses of eligible students. The Code is amended to redefine "eligible student" and make a deduction permanent. The amendments apply to payments after December 31, 2002. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR INTEREST ON HIGHER EDUCATION LOANS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section allowing for a credit for interest on higher education loans. A credit is allowed against the tax for individuals for interest paid on qualified education loans, with a maximum credit of $1,500. The credit amount is reduced if the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeds $50,000 ($100,000 for joint returns). The credit amount is reduced if the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeds $50,000 ($100,000 for joint returns), with adjustments for inflation after 2003. The credit amount is adjusted for inflation by substituting '2002' for '1992' and rounding to the nearest multiple of $50. No credit is allowed if a deduction for the individual is claimed by another taxpayer. The credit is limited to the first 60 months of interest paid on a qualified education loan. The tax credit for education loans is limited to the first 60 months of interest payments on a qualified education loan. Special rules apply, such as no double benefit allowed and married couples must file a joint return to claim the credit. Taxpayers can claim the education loan credit only if they file a joint return with their spouse. Marital status is determined according to section 7703. The amendments made by this section apply to qualified education loans incurred before or after the enactment date of the Act, with regards to loan interest payments due after December 31, 2002.
